intro: Tragacantha elegans, commonly known as the Persian gum or Astragalus, is a flowering plant native to the Middle East and Central Asia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, yellowish flowers. The plant produces a valuable gum resin, which has been used historically in traditional medicine and as a food additive. Its leaves are trifoliate, and it thrives in arid and semi-arid environments. Tragacantha elegans is also known for its ecological importance in stabilizing soils in dry regions.
